Press Me

example 2

I did this to help me understand whats going on with keyframe animations. This image is 2000px wide and has ten different "frames" of the animation repeated all the way across. The code takes ten "steps" down the image, doing the math for me, literally shifting the image position in the background. So, "play .8s steps(10) infinite"... if you were to change the number of steps to "steps(11)" (like is shown in the animation below) then the animation would change. There are only ten frames on a fixed dimension image, so telling the computer that there are 11 frams then divides the pasted code into eleven parts and essentially renders the animation worthless. I copy and pasted this code, and then destroyed it, for science.

Sauce: http://jsfiddle.net/simurai/CGmCe/light/

example 3 [fixed thanks to error report]

Here's another time sucker upper that I basically copied, studied the code through breaking it and made it sort of my own. (I promise, ill be creating for myself here shortly.) I discovered some new-to-me translate animations, translate3d(x-axis, y-axis, z-axis) is interesting. It was used in this animation of Bromswell on the seperate png's of his body. The head has a slight breathing motion to it as does the body.
Sauce: http://samuli.hakoniemi.net/having-fun-with-css-keyframes/

example 5

It works so im going with it... now if i could just find where in my code i went wrong...
[Edit, thanks to error reporting, i was able to fix many of the bugs that plagued this whole page]

example 10

You have to apply the different transforms to different classes... i think im getting that correct...

example 13

This one is pretty interesting. Taken primarily from codepen & rewritten, it uses an animation on the background called "pulse". It begins at scale(0);opacity:1;, so its visible completely underneath the static forground (at z-index:10;) then transforms to it's native size and to opacity:0;. I would not have put that technique together on my own but sweet, ill use it. I also made it fade faster.
Sauce: http://codepen.io/KoniG87/pen/gktdi

example 21

That's pretty cool. It is pretty much just like it's source, but i did go through and write it. The scale transformation goes from flat to vertically compressed, spending most of its time on the screen skinny, and in true animated form, reaches the top of it's cycle and shoots back down to the shadow. Very cool, although i'm not entirely positive on percentages and how to REALLY use them as of yet.
Sauce: http://codepen.io/joshbader/pen/mpFir
